title: Let's talk about the pay gap in banking and law
text:
One scoop to start: JAB Holding, the European investment group behind brands such as Pret A Manger, Panera Bread and Krispy Kreme, is seeking to raise a fresh $5bn fund to extend its spree of dealmaking in the booming petcare sector.

UK data shows pay gap widens despite pressure

Any DD reader who has spent more than a few seconds glancing at the partner lists of big banks and law firms knows that the vast majority of those roles are occupied by men.

And in the UK, at least, efforts to close the pay gap between men and women are proving hard work. Despite moves by the government and regulators to stem the divide, the gap is actually widening even further, according to this less-than-cheery FT analysis.

Among the biggest offenders are banks and law firms.

When Jane Fraser was appointed as Citigroup's chief executive last year, we said a plexiglass ceiling had been shattered on Wall Street. And it was true. She's the first woman to lead a big US bank in an industry where male ‘forever CEOs' are clinging to their crowns.

But change at the very top is not everything. According to the FT's analysis, women in the UK were paid 87p for every £1 paid to men in April 2020 — when the government compiled the latest figures. This has worsened since 2019, when the pay gap was 12.8 per cent, and  2018, when the gap was 11.9 per cent.

At banks and law firms, which displayed some of the largest pay gaps, much of the imbalance has been attributed to the fact that fewer women occupy senior roles.

Richard Gnodde, head of Goldman Sachs International — where the median hourly pay gap has increased from 34.4 per cent in 2019 to 36.8 per cent in 2020 — summarises the arguments that many in the industry make: “This issue remains a critical priority for the firm . . . it is working, but it takes time.”

Here's how the median hourly pay gaps at the UK arms of prominent banks have evolved over the years:

While banking's culture of perma-CEOs has made it difficult for women to enter the industry's top ranks, disparities at the lower rungs persist too.

Lloyds, where the gap was almost 34 per cent last year, said the difference reflects the fact that it still had “a higher proportion of women in more junior levels and fewer women in more senior roles”. At a bonus level, the gap was about 70 per cent.

In the world of Big Law, wage gaps have climbed at elite firms over the years. Women were paid 47.4 per cent less than men per hour on average at Slaughter and May compared to 45 per cent in 2018, with Allen & Overy trailing close behind with a 46.4 per cent gap from 39 per cent two years prior.

Here's how wage gaps have changed at top UK firms:

As an industry-wide talent war sends pay packages skyrocketing at Magic Circle firms and their US rivals, it remains to be seen whether the “golden handcuff” arrangements are being bestowed upon women as much as they are men. (Catch up on that story in Wednesday's edition.)

It comes at a time when the pandemic has placed disproportionate pressure on women to look after children during lockdowns, with men often the first to return to offices.

The luxury property graveyards of London

Shares in Evergrande, which were suspended earlier this week, aren't the only thing on hiatus.

Many high-end London flats bankrolled by the Chinese developers lie unfinished and unsold, the FT's George Hammond and Thomas Hale report.

As the Evergrande crisis plays out, “the big question is whether the Chinese will restrict investment overseas”, one property consultant said. “That would be a pretty big crisis in the UK and elsewhere.”

Once a favourite of developers from China and Hong Kong, who poured £3.5bn into London between 2013 and 2018, the sector has taken a nosedive amid new taxes on foreign buyers and the uncertainty sown by three general elections and the Brexit referendum.

The 235-metre “Spire London”, touted to become western Europe's tallest residential tower by Chinese property developer Greenland Group, has yet to materialise near London's Canary Wharf. While the company insists the project is ongoing, an estate agent based opposite the site says there's been “no activity for as long as I can remember.” 

Country Garden, a Guangdong-based developer and the largest in China by sales, similarly has a luxury development that is yet to be constructed.

Chinese developers, who once flocked to London, were already under regulatory pressure from Beijing to curb excessive leverage and limit their borrowing before Evergrande's problems made the front pages.

Now the question is whether half-erected structures could become a more common fixture across London's skyline.

Merck's new CEO prescribed a hefty dose of M&A

When Rob Davis took the helm of Merck in April, the pharmaceutical company needed a chief executive with just as much of a nose for M&A as they did for breakthrough medicines.

Merck's patent for Keytruda, its golden goose of an immunotherapy treatment that has raised the survival odds of thousands of patients and the company's bottom line, is due to expire in 2028. (And in pharma years, where it takes on average a decade and $2.6bn of investment to make a new drug, that's not actually a very long time.)

Last week investors received an initial glimpse of what that dealmaking strategy could look like when Merck agreed to pay $11.5bn for Acceleron Pharma, a biotech company that develops protein-based therapies to treat a rare blood pressure disorder and some cancers.

Davis said the deal would help to diversify Merck's portfolio and that he was scouring for other targets in preparation for an inevitable decline in sales when the clock runs out on its signature cancer wonder drug.

Those targets could include Mirati Therapeutics, a clinical-stage biotech company with a market value of $8bn, Strand Therapeutics, a developer of mRNA therapeutics for cancer immunotherapy, or potentially the $41bn US biotech group Biogen, people briefed on the matter told DD's James Fontanella-Khan.

Some find the latter unlikely, however, doubting that Davis would invite the type of regulatory scrutiny that comes with trying to get a pharma mega-deal over the line.

“This is the first step on a journey to continue to build out our pipeline so that we have the ability to grow sustainably well into the next decade . . . we won't be limited by the balance sheet,” he told the FT.

He has some catching up to do. Even as Keytruda has transformed the company, bringing in just under a third of its total revenue of $48bn last year, Merck has lagged behind rivals during the pandemic, failing to launch its own Covid-19 vaccine.

And while Merck's trials for an antiviral pill poised to reduce the risk of hospitalisation or death from Covid-19 by approximately 50 per cent are beginning to look promising, the drug still wouldn't have the moneymaking potential to replace Keytruda.

Perhaps Davis has some tricks up his sleeve to strengthen the immunity of Merck's balance sheet.

Job moves

  • Finsbury Glover Hering has acquired the Washington-based public affairs firm The Harbour Group. Separately, Craig Oliver, the former Downing Street director of communications under David Cameron, and Amber Rudd, the former UK home secretary, have left their senior roles at the troubled PR firm Teneo to join FGH as its new head of strategic communications and a senior adviser, respectively.

  • Bobby Tudor and Maynard Holt, two of the founders of the boutique energy investment bank Tudor Pickering Holt & Co, are retiring from the firm, says Reuters.

  • RBC Capital Markets has appointed JPMorgan Chase alum and former National Australia Bank chief operating officer Natalie Vanstone as a managing director and head of global markets in Australia, based in Sydney.

  • Ashurst has hired Wes Strickland as partner in its projects practice, based in Los Angeles. He joins from Holland & Knight. The firm has also hired Helen Jones as a partner in its global markets practice, based in London. She joins from Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer.
